bibl.title: Letter from H.D. Thomason to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 1, 1908

div1.p: Thomason discusses a yellow fever patient, Manuel Casas.

div1.head: Letter from H.D. Thomason to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 1, 1908
div1.opener:
REPUBLIC OF CUBA
---
UNDER THE PROVISIONAL ADMINISTRATION OF THE
UNITED STATES
-----
OFFICE OF SPECIAL COMMISSIONER NATIONAL
SANITARY DEPARTMENT
---
Sept. 1/08
Dr Finlay to
read & return-
I C
My Dear Major-
div1.p:
I enclose clinical chart of Manuel
Casas to date. It is a puzzling case. As I
telegraphed you this P.M. I think case is positive
& this is based upon the impression I obtained from
the classical symptoms of the 27th, & which continued on
the 28th - on the 29th conditions presented themselves that
threw an element of doubt on the corrections of first opinion-
Guitteras is strongly of the opinion that the case is a positive
one, but out of defrence to Fauntleroy, opposite opinion
& my desire that in the event of a reasonable doubt
existing the Govt. should recieve the benefit of this
as a positive diagnosis meant so much to Cuba,
he decided to work delay announcement until
tomorrow. I left Fauntleroy & Guitteras over
REPUBLIC OF CUBA
---
UNDER THE PROVISIONAL ADMINISTRATION OF THE
UNITED STATES
-----
OFFICE OF SPECIAL COMMISSIONER NATIONAL
SANITARY DEPARTMENT
---
at Fimieza, the latter former goes to Vincent tonight,
but both will return here tomorrow & we will
have another talk over the case- Certainly the pa-
tient's symptoms on the 27th were such that no
other conclusion could be reached than that the case
presented a classical picture of yellow fever at that
stages. In Fauntleroy's opinion & mine the man also
has pneumonia, & to our minds the physical sign
are plain, but Guitteras does not concern in this,
but regards the lung symptoms merely hyperaestatic
congestion. He has rusty sputum & I believe has
pneumonia though of course I hesitate to talk is-
one with so experta diagnostitian as Guitteras, on
matter of physical signs.
